Two multidrug-resistant E119D and E119D-H274Y pH1N1 variants were evaluated for their pathogenic potential and transmissibility in ferrets because their viral fitness was comprehensively retained.
Viruses were transmitted to three naive contact ferrets in the E119D group

pH1N1 viruses possessing the NA H274Y substitution were comparable to their oseltamivir-sensitive counterparts not only in in vitro NA inhibition assays but also in their pathogenicity and transmissibility in animal models
our study, showed that inducing E119A/D/G and V mutations in the N1 subtype of influenza A viruses confers NAI resistance, mainly to zanamivir.
E119 mutations conferred reduced susceptibility mainly to zanamivir, suggesting that selective pressure is exerted by zanamivir in the N1 subtype.
The E119A/D/G mutations in H5N1 conferred resistance, particularly to zanamivir
the E119D mutation conferred resistance to all of the NAIs, mainly to zanamivir (Table 1)
